'''LIV Golf''' ({{IPAc-en|l|ɪ|v}}) is a [[professional golf tour]] financed by the [[Public Investment Fund]], the [[sovereign wealth fund]] of [[Saudi Arabia]]. The name "LIV" refers to the [[Roman numeral]]s for 54, the score if every hole on a par-72 course were [[Birdie (golf)|birdied]] and the number of holes to be played at LIV events.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.si.com/golf/news/faq-liv-golf-invitational-series | title=FAQ of the LIV Golf Invitational Series: Field Taking Shape for First Event |date=2022-05-31 |last=Harig |first=Bob |magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]] |accessdate= 2022-06-06}}</ref> The first '''LIV Golf Invitational Series''' event started on 9 June 2022, at the [[Centurion Club]] near London, England. The Invitational Series is to become the '''LIV Golf League''' in 2023.

The tour has been accused by Western media sources of being used by the [[Saudi monarchy]], which has been criticized for its [[Politics of Saudi Arabia#Corruption|corruption]] and [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights abuses]], to [[sportswashing|improve its public image through sports]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Schad |first=Tom |title=LIV Golf shines spotlight on 'sportswashing' – the nascent term for an age-old strategy |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/golf/2022/06/10/sportswashing-explained-saudis-liv-golf/10003676002/ |access-date=2022-10-14 |website=USA Today}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Friedman |first=Thomas L. |author-link=Thomas Friedman |date=2022-06-14 |title=Opinion {{!}} Saudi Arabia Should Take a Mulligan on Golf. Here's What It Can Do Instead. |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/14/opinion/saudi-arabia-khashoggi-pga.html |access-date=2022-10-14 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Feinstein |first=John |author-link=John Feinstein |date=February 25, 2022 |title=Opinion {{!}} How Phil Mickelson got clocked by his own backswing |language=en-US |work=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/02/25/what-phil-mickelson-forgot/ |access-date=2022-10-14 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=July 1, 2022 |title=Saudi-backed LIV Golf shows how ‘sportswashing’ can backfire |work=Fast Company |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90765385/liv-golf-saudi-arabia-sportswashing-backlash}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Moulton |first=Aaron Coy |date=October 14, 2022 |title=Perspective {{!}} LIV Golf is changing the role of golf in 'sportswashing' |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/made-by-history/2022/10/14/liv-sportswashing-golf-dominican-republic/ |access-date=2022-10-14 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

==Organization==
[[File:Greg Norman 2014.jpg|thumb|[[Greg Norman]], [[Chief Executive Officer]] of LIV Golf (2014 image).]] 
The early framework for a new golf tour to rival the [[PGA Tour]] became public in 2019 with announcement of a league to be known as the Premier Golf League.<ref name="GD20220216">{{cite magazine |last1=Beall |first1=Joel |title=The Saudi golf tour: What we know, what we don't and everything else you might not understand about the proposed new league |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/saudi-golf-league-2022-primer |magazine=[[Golf Digest]] |date=February 16, 2022}}</ref><ref name="beall-june1">{{cite magazine |last=Beall |first=Joel |date=1 June 2022 |title=The LIV Golf series: What we know, what we don't, and the massive ramifications of the Saudi-backed league |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/saudi-golf-league-2022-primer |access-date=2022-06-05 |magazine=[[Golf Digest]]}}</ref> PGA Tour Commissioner [[Jay Monahan]] responded by implying that golfers who choose to play in a new league would be barred from PGA Tour events.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Beall |first=Joel |title=Why a potential rival league could ultimately benefit the PGA Tour |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/why-a-potential-rival-league-premier-golf-league-could-ultimately-benefit-the-pga-tour |magazine=[[Golf Digest]] |date=January 31, 2020}}</ref> Later in 2020, the [[PGA European Tour]] and the PGA Tour formed a "strategic alliance" to work together on commercial opportunities, scheduling, and prize funds for each tour's membership.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Herrington |first=Ryan |title=PGA Tour, European Tour announce formation of a strategic alliance |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/pga-tour-and-european-tour-announce-strategic-alliance |magazine=[[Golf Digest]] |date=November 27, 2020}}</ref>

The Premier Golf League held talks with Saudi investors about a financial partnership,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.sports.yahoo.com/news/driving-super-golf-league-115448994.html/ |last=Casey  |first=Phil |title=What is driving the Super Golf League? |work=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |publisher=[[PA Media]] |date=2022-02-04 |accessdate=2022-06-06}}</ref> but Golf Saudi (a division of the [[Public Investment Fund]]) instead funded a new entity in 2020 which had its own plan to establish a global professional league,<ref name="Bamberger" /> often referred to as the "Super Golf League". This entity formally launched in October 2021 as LIV Golf Investments,<ref name="beall-june1" /> with former professional golfer [[Greg Norman]] named as CEO.<ref name="Bamberger">{{cite news |last=Bamberger |first=Michael |title='This is only the beginning': Greg Norman to helm Saudi-funded golf investment group, reveals plans |url=https://golf.com/news/greg-norman-ceo-saudi-funded-liv-investments-asian-tour/ |work=Golf.com |date=October 29, 2021}}</ref>

LIV Golf has often been described as the golfing equivalent to the dormant breakaway [[European Super League]] in football.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-02-03 |title=What is driving the Super Golf League? |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/driving-super-golf-league-115448994.html |access-date=2022-06-08 |website=Yahoo! Sports |last=Casey |first=Phil}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Lees |first=Joshua |date=2022-06-08 |title=Dustin Johnson turns his back on legacy all for the riches of golf's ESL equivalent |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/golf/1622580/Dustin-Johnson-legacy-ESL-LIV-Series-Golf-news |access-date=2022-06-08 |newspaper=Daily Express}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-05-12 |title=The Saudi Golf League And Other Breakaway Competitions In Sport |url=https://www.thesportsman.com/articles/the-saudi-golf-league-and-other-breakaway-competitions-in-sport |access-date=2022-06-08 |website=The Sportsman}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Campigotto |first=Jesse |date=2021-05-05 |title=The Super League of golf, explained |work=[[CBC Sports]] |url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/the-buzzer-newsletter-golf-super-league-1.6015347 |access-date=2022-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-05-09 |title=Winning in a world of super leagues and constant change |url=https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Journal/Issues/2022/05/09/Opinion/Opinion.aspx |access-date=2022-06-08 |newspaper=Sports Business Journal}}</ref>

In July 2022, LIV Golf formally applied to be included in the [[Official World Golf Ranking]], a process which typically takes between a year and two years from application submission to approval and awarding of OWGR points.<ref>{{cite web |last=Schlabach |first=Mark |title=LIV Golf's application to be included in rankings mulled by OWGR |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34235229/liv-application-ranking-mulled-official-board-governors |work=ESPN |access-date=6 October 2022 |date=13 July 2022}}</ref> In October 2022, LIV Golf entered into a "strategic alliance" with the [[MENA Tour]]; the arrangement was conceived in order to immediately afford LIV Golf events ranking points,<ref>{{Cite news |last=Corrigan |first=James |date=5 October 2022 |title=Exclusive: LIV golfers find way to earn world ranking points – from this week |newspaper=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/golf/2022/10/05/exclusive-liv-golfers-earn-world-ranking-points/ |access-date=5 October 2022}}</ref> however it was subsequently confirmed that events in 2022 would not receive points as changes to the MENA Tour would need to be reviewed.<ref>{{cite web |title=LIV Golf events this season to miss out on world ranking points despite new MENA Tour alliance |url=https://www.skysports.com/golf/news/12176/12713547/liv-golf-events-this-season-to-miss-out-on-world-ranking-points-despite-new-mena-tour-alliance |website=Sky Sports |access-date=6 October 2022 |date=6 October 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Harig |first=Bob |title=World Ranking Officials Will Take Time to Review LIV Golf's Shrewd Idea for Points |url=https://www.si.com/golf/news/world-ranking-officials-to-review-liv-golf-idea-for-points |magazine=Sports Illustrated |access-date=6 October 2022 |date=6 October 2022}}</ref>

===Format=== 
The inaugural season of the LIV Golf Invitational Series features eight 54-hole no-cut [[stroke play]] tournaments and a final Team Championship, set to be a "seeded four-day, four-round, [[match play]] knock-out" event held at [[Trump National Doral Miami]] in October 2022.<ref name="LivGolfFormat">{{cite web |title=LIV Golf Format |url=https://www.livgolf.com/format |publisher=LIV Golf |access-date=27 July 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="LivGolfFormatGolfMonthly">{{cite web |last=Hibbitt |first=James |title=What Is The LIV Golf Series Format? |url=https://www.golfmonthly.com/news/what-is-the-liv-golf-series-format |magazine=Golf Monthly |access-date=27 July 2022 |date=28 June 2022}}</ref>

In June 2022, it was reported that LIV Golf would evolve the following year into a league format with a 14-event schedule and 48 contracted players.<ref>{{Cite magazine |date=30 June 2022 |title=LIV Golf to transition to 'league' schedule in 2023, with 14 events and 48 contracted players |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/liv-golf-league-schedule-2023 |access-date=1 July 2022 |magazine=Golf Digest |first=Dan |last=Rapaport}}</ref> On 27 July 2022, Norman announced that LIV Golf would implement a [[promotion and relegation]] system, featuring a rankings list and a four-player relegation out of the 48 contracted players.<ref>{{Cite magazine |date=25 July 2022 |title=Exclusive: LIV Golf's Future Plans Include Relegation, Qualifying Tournament |url=https://www.si.com/golf/news/liv-golfs-future-plans-include-relegation-qualifying-tournament |access-date=26 July 2022 |magazine=Sports Illustrated |first=Alex |last=Miceli}}</ref><ref name="LIVGolfLeaguePressRelease">{{cite web |title=LIV Golf Announces 2023 League Launch With 48 Players, 12 Established Team Franchises, 14-Event Schedule |publisher=LIV Golf |url=https://www.livgolf.com/news/liv-golf-announces-2023-league-launch-48-players-12-established-teams-14-events |date=27 July 2022 |access-date=27 July 2022}}</ref> The league has a prize fund of $405 million. Its events are scheduled to avoid competing with PGA Tour [[Men's major golf championships|majors]] and international team events.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/golf/62325369 |title=LIV Golf announces $405m 14-event league for 2023 that will not clash with majors |access-date=27 July 2022 |work=BBC Sport}}</ref>

===Broadcasting rights===
The 2022 LIV Golf Invitational Series is streamed live on [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]].

In June 2022, LIV Golf signed a worldwide broadcasting deal with video streaming service [[DAZN]]. Additional deals were signed the following months, including [[ServusTV]] in Germany and Austria, [[Eleven Sports]] in Italy, [[Claro (company)|Claro Sports]] in Latin America, and [[CHCH-TV]] in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada.

==Player signups==
On 1 June 2022, the field was released for the first event, to be played at the [[Centurion Club]]. The list included several major champions and former world number ones: [[Dustin Johnson]], [[Sergio García]], [[Martin Kaymer]], [[Graeme McDowell]], [[Louis Oosthuizen]], [[Charl Schwartzel]] and [[Lee Westwood]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/golf/61641439 |title=LIV Golf: Dustin Johnson, Sergio Garcia, Lee Westwood and Ian Poulter to play at inaugural $25m event |website=BBC Sport |date=1 June 2022 |access-date=1 June 2022}}</ref> One source said Johnson {{ndash}} winner of two [[Men's major golf championships|major championships]] and a former [[List of world number one male golfers|World No. 1]] {{ndash}} was paid US$150 million to play in the LIV series.<ref name="corrigan">{{cite news |author1=James Corrigan |title=Dustin Johnson paid £100m to perform late U-turn and join Saudi-backed rebel series |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/dustin-johnson-u-turns-pga-063419874.html |access-date=6 June 2022 |work=Yahoo Sports |agency=The Daily Telegraph |date=31 May 2022}}</ref> Johnson, who had won 24 PGA events and $74 million since 2008, announced his resignation from the Tour on 7 June 2022,<ref name="espn">{{cite news |first=Kevin |last=Van Valkenburg |title=Dustin Johnson resigns from PGA Tour to play in rival LIV Golf series |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34051209/dustin-johnson-resigns-pga-tour-play-rival-liv-series |work=ESPN |date=7 June 2022 |access-date=7 June 2022}}</ref> saying, "I chose what's best for me and my family."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dustin Johnson confirms PGA Tour resignation and Ryder Cup ineligibility: 'LIV format is true test' |url=https://www.skysports.com/golf/news/12176/12629313/dustin-johnson-confirms-pga-resignation-and-ryder-cup-illegibility-liv-format-is-true-test |access-date=2022-06-08 |website=Sky Sports}}</ref> [[Ian Poulter]] was reportedly offered £22 million (US$30 million) to join the league.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Corrigan |first=James |date=February 1, 2022 |title=Exclusive: Saudi Arabia offers Ian Poulter £22m to ditch Ryder Cup and join rebel golf tour |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/golf/2022/02/01/saudi-arabia-offers-ian-poulter-22m-ditch-ryder-cup-join-rebel/ |url-access=subscription |access-date=February 16, 2022}}</ref> Lee Westwood said that he had signed a [[non-disclosure agreement]] relating to the topic.<ref>{{Cite news |date=February 2, 2022 |title=Dustin Johnson coy about Super Golf League offer; Westwood has NDA |url=https://www.golfchannel.com/news/dustin-johnson-lee-westwood-intrigued-team-concept-mum-sgl-offers |access-date=February 16, 2022 |work=[[Golf Channel]]}}</ref>

On 4 June 2022, [[Kevin Na]] became the first member of the PGA Tour to resign to participate in LIV Golf, saying, "If I exercise my right to choose where and when I play golf, then I cannot remain a PGA Tour player without facing disciplinary proceedings and legal action from the PGA Tour.... I hope the current policies change and I'll be able to play on the PGA Tour again."<ref name="schlabach"/> Reigning [[U.S. Amateur]] champion [[James Piot]], who turned professional in May 2022, chose to play in the first LIV Golf tournament without having joined the PGA Tour.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shedloski |first1=James |title=James Piot just turned pro but has the 2021 U.S. Amateur champ already jeopardized his career by signing with LIV Golf? |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/james-piot-liv-golf-future-pro-career |website=[[Golf Digest]] |access-date=2022-06-05 |date=5 June 2022}}</ref>

In a ''[[Washington Post]]'' interview published on 5 June 2022, LIV Golf CEO Greg Norman said that [[Tiger Woods]] had declined to join, turning down a deal that was "mind-blowingly enormous; we're talking about high nine digits."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Babb |first=Kent |date=2022-06-05 |title=The Shark is on the attack again |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2022/06/05/last-attack-greg-norman/ |access-date=2022-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Report: The 'mind-blowingly enormous' money Tiger Woods declined to join LIV Golf |url=https://golf.com/news/tiger-woods-liv-golf/ |access-date=2022-06-08 |website=Golf.com|last1=Kerr-Dineen|first1=Luke|date=6 June 2022}}</ref>

Before the [[LIV Golf Invitational Portland|second event in Portland]], LIV Golf announced further signings, including several players in the top-50 of the world rankings, and three more major champions: [[Bryson DeChambeau]], [[Brooks Koepka]], and [[Patrick Reed]]. During that event, it was announced that [[Paul Casey]] would play in the [[LIV Golf Invitational Bedminster|third event in Bedminster]]. Further signings before Bedminster included European [[Ryder Cup]] captain [[Henrik Stenson]], who was removed from the role before the move was announced.<ref>{{cite web |first1=Patrick |last1=McDonald |first2=Kyle |last2=Porter |title=Henrik Stenson stripped of 2023 Ryder Cup captaincy amid rumored defection to LIV Golf Invitational Series |url=https://www.cbssports.com/golf/news/henrik-stenson-stripped-of-2023-ryder-cup-captaincy-amid-rumored-defection-to-liv-golf-invitational-series/ |website=CBS Sports |access-date=20 July 2022 |date=20 July 2022}}</ref> In August 2022, before the [[LIV Golf Invitational Boston|fourth event in Boston]], LIV Golf announced that six more players had joined, including Open champion and world number two [[Cameron Smith (golfer)|Cameron Smith]] and Chilean world number 19 [[Joaquín Niemann]].<ref name=smithboston>{{cite news |title=Open champion Cameron Smith, five others leave PGA Tour for LIV Golf |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34487307/open-champion-cameron-smith-five-others-leave-pga-tour-liv-golf |work=ESPN |last=Schlabach |first=Mark |date=30 August 2022 |access-date=30 August 2022}}</ref>

==Reaction==
Human rights groups have criticized LIV Golf as [[sportswashing]], a political strategy by Saudi Arabia to cleanse its [[Political repression|repressive]] global image<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Worst of the Worst: The World’s Most Repressive Societies 2012 |url=https://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Worst%20of%20the%20Worst%202012%20final%20report.pdf |access-date=October 12, 2022 |website=Freedom House |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710044032/https://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Worst%20of%20the%20Worst%202012%20final%20report.pdf |archive-date=July 10, 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> through sport.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Schad |first1=Tom |date=10 June 2022 |title=LIV Golf shines spotlight on 'sportswashing' – the nascent term for an age-old strategy |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/golf/2022/06/10/sportswashing-explained-saudis-liv-golf/10003676002/ |accessdate=10 June 2022 |website=USA Today}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]], for example, called the Saudi endeavor “an effort to distract from its serious [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights abuses]] by taking over events that celebrate human achievement”.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Noble |first=Josh |date=10 October 2022 |title=Saudi Arabia wealth fund commits $2.3bn to football sponsorships |work=Financial Times |url=https://www.ft.com/content/ce556bac-30cc-49c6-b883-5cab67ce5379 |access-date=10 October 2022}}</ref> 

Greg Norman has been accused of aiding the repressive Saudi government for his own financial gain.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2021/11/06/the-stench-of-david-beckham-greg-norman-profiting-off-middle-east-money/|title=The stench of David Beckham, Greg Norman profiting off Middle East money|access-date=6 November 2021|website=New York Post|last1=Newsham|first1=Gavin|date=6 November 2021}}</ref> In 2021, Norman denied that he was being used for sportswashing and said he works for LIV because of his passion for the sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a770c525-7241-4ee4-8db2-5b0f7c4cd568 |title=Disrupting golf: the Saudi-backed plan to shake up the sport |accessdate=25 November 2021|website=The Financial Times}}</ref> Later, in May 2022, Norman defended the involvement of Saudi Crown Prince [[Mohammed bin Salman]] with [[Jamal Khashoggi]]’s [[Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi|murder]], saying, “Look, we've all made mistakes, and you just want to learn from those mistakes and how you can correct them going forward.” His statement drew extensive criticism. Khashoggi’s fiancée, Hatice Cengiz, said it was hurtful that “Jamal's brutal killing is brushed off as a 'mistake' and that we should just move on”.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/33903599/greg-norman-refers-jamal-khashoggi-killing-mistake-drawing-backlash-liv-golf-clarification|title=Greg Norman refers to Jamal Khashoggi killing as 'mistake,' drawing backlash, LIV Golf clarification|access-date=12 May 2022|website=ESPN |date=12 May 2022|last1=Schalbach|first1=Mark}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2022/05/12/greg-norman-saudi-golf-mistake/|title=Greg Norman criticized for downplaying Saudis' killing of Jamal Khashoggi|accessdate=12 May 2022 |newspaper=The Washington Post|last1=Bonesteel|first1=Matt|date=12 May 2022}}</ref>

On 22 June 2022, a group of nearly 2,500 survivors of family members killed or injured during the [[September 11 attacks]] wrote an open letter to golfers who have remained loyal to the PGA Tour thanking them for not defecting to LIV Golf. The letter read in part: "Thank you for standing up for decency. Thank you for standing up for the 9/11 Families. Thank you for resisting the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's efforts to cleanse its reputation by buying off professional athletes...To those of you who have chosen what is right over blood money from a corrupt, destructive sports entity and its Saudi backers, please continue to stand strong."<ref>{{Cite web |title=9/11 group thanks golfers for rejecting Saudis |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/911-group-golfers-rejecting-saudis/story?id=85559450 |access-date=2022-06-23 |website=ABC News|date=22 June 2022 |first1=Mark|last1=Schlabach}}</ref> On 17 July 2022, a group of September 11 victims' family members condemned former U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] for hosting the LIV Golf tour at his [[Trump National Golf Club Bedminster|Trump National Golf Club]] in [[Bedminster, New Jersey]]; the group's letter to Trump noted that he himself had blamed Saudi Arabia for the 9/11 attack during a 2016 interview on [[Fox News]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/17/us/politics/trump-liv-golf-bedminster.html |title=9/11 Families Call on Trump to Cancel Saudi-Backed Golf Event |newspaper=The New York Times |first=Azi |last=Paybarah |date=17 July 2022 |access-date=17 July 2022}}</ref>

[[Tiger Woods]], who turned down an offer of $700 million to $800 million to join LIV Golf,<ref>{{Cite news |last=Schlabach |first=Mark |date=2022-08-02 |title=Norman: LIV's offer to Tiger in $700-$800M range |work=ESPN |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34330962/tiger-woods-turned-offer-neighborhood-700-800-million-approached-join-liv-golf-greg-norman-says |access-date=2022-08-02}}</ref> was asked in July 2022 about the golfers who had joined. "I disagree with it. I think that what they've done is they've turned their back on what has allowed them to get to this position," Woods said at a press conference before the [[2022 Open Championship]]. "I know what the PGA Tour stands for and what we have done and what the tour has given us, the ability to chase after our careers and to earn what we get and the trophies we have been able to play for and the history that has been a part of this game."<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-07-12 |title=Tiger: LIV players 'turned their back' on PGA Tour |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34230611/tiger-woods-says-just-understand-how-liv-players-give-chance-play-major-championship |access-date=2022-07-15 |work=ESPN |first=Mark |last=Schlabach}}</ref>   

===PGA Tour===

The [[PGA Tour]] announced that its members who participate in LIV Golf events could be sanctioned for playing in a conflicting event without the Tour's permission,<ref>{{cite news |title=LIV Golf Invitational: PGA Tour says it will sanction players who compete in London event |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/golf/61662624 |work=BBC Sport |date=1 June 2022 |access-date=2022-06-05}}</ref> which could result in fines, suspensions, or bans.<ref name="schlabach">{{cite news |last=Schlabach |first=Mark |title=Kevin Na resigns from PGA Tour, will participate in LIV Golf series |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34036642/kevin-na-resigns-pga-tour-participate-liv-golf-series |work=ESPN |date=4 June 2022 |access-date=2022-06-05}}</ref> On 9 June 2022, the PGA Tour announced that its members participating in the first LIV Golf tournament (including current members as well as those who had recently resigned) were no longer eligible to compete in tour events or the [[Presidents Cup]].<ref name="Schlabach">{{cite news |url=https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/34063037/pga-tour-suspends-all-players-taking-part-first-liv-golf-tournament |title=PGA Tour suspends all players taking part in first LIV Golf tournament |last=Schlabach |first=Mark |work=ESPN |date=June 9, 2022 |access-date=June 8, 2022}}</ref> By contrast, the constitution of the [[European Tour]] does not provide for banning players who enter conflicting events.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Huggan |first=John |title=The tricky situation facing the DP World Tour as it braces for LIV Golf |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/dp-world-tour-challenge-liv-golf-pga-tour-future |magazine =[[Golf Digest]] |access-date=2022-06-05 |date=8 May 2022}}</ref>

On 11 July 2022, it was reported that the [[United States Department of Justice]] was investigating the PGA Tour to determine if they have engaged in anti-competitive behavior with LIV Golf.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Louise |last1=Radnofsky |first2=Andrew |last2=Beaton |date=2022-07-11 |title=Justice Department Is Investigating PGA Tour Over Potential Antitrust Violations in LIV Golf Battle |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/pga-tour-antitrust-liv-department-of-justice-investigation-11657557177 |access-date=2022-07-11}}</ref>

In September, it was reported that a letter had been sent to [[Japan Golf Tour]] members notifying them that the PGA Tour would exclude LIV Golf players from their co-sanctioned events, such as the [[Zozo Championship]], even if they were not members of the PGA Tour. It was speculated as the reason that all four Japanese players who had played in earlier events had withdrawn from the series prior to the fourth event in Boston.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Harig |first=Bob |title=Exclusive: PGA Tour Threatens to Ban Japan Golf Tour Players Who Compete in LIV Golf Events |url=https://www.si.com/golf/news/pga-tour-threatens-ban-japan-golf-tour-players-who-compete-liv-golf-events |magazine=Sports Illustrated  |date=1 September 2022 |access-date=2 September 2022}}</ref> It was also reported that a letter had been sent to PGA Tour members who had joined LIV Golf but not resigned their membership of the PGA Tour advising them that their membership would "not be renewed for the [[2022–23 PGA Tour|2022–23 season]]".<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Harig |first=Bob |title=Former PGA Tour Players Now With LIV Have Memberships Revoked for Next Season |url=https://www.si.com/golf/news/former-pga-tour-players-now-with-liv-have-memberships-revoked-for-next-season |magazine=Sports Illustrated |date=2 September 2022 |access-date=2 September 2022}}</ref>

===European Tour===

In June 2022, the PGA and European tours announced a strengthening of their "strategic alliance", with the PGA Tour increasing their stake in European Tour Productions to 40% and further changes being made to the European Tour, including increased prize funds and leading players in the DP World Tour Rankings gaining PGA Tour cards for the following season.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Carter |first1=Iain |title=LIV Golf: DP World & PGA Tours strengthen partnership to combat Saudi-funded series |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/golf/61975762 |work=BBC Sport |access-date=29 June 2022 |date=28 June 2022}}</ref>

The European Tour did not take any disciplinary action until the end of June, when it was announced that LIV Golf participants would be fined and suspended from the European Tour's three PGA Tour co-sanctioned events.<ref>{{cite web |title=DP World Tour: LIV players to be fined and suspended; Players suspended from Scottish Open |url=https://www.skysports.com/golf/news/12176/12639452/dp-world-tour-liv-players-to-be-fined-and-suspended-players-suspended-from-scottish-open |website=Sky Sports |access-date=July 12, 2022 |date=June 24, 2022}}</ref> Several players, including [[Ian Poulter]], took legal action and the suspensions were put on hold, allowing them to play in the [[Genesis Scottish Open]] and subsequent tour events pending a full hearing,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Carter |first1=Iain |title=Ian Poulter allowed to play Scottish Open after ban lifted - DP World Tour boss 'disappointed' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/golf/62035651 |website=BBC Sport |access-date=July 12, 2022 |date=July 4, 2022}}</ref> which was scheduled by Sport Resolutions UK for February 2023.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Murray |first1=Ewan |title=LIV Golf rebels handed February date for decision over DP World Tour future |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/aug/30/dp-world-tour-sets-february-date-for-decision-over-liv-golf-rebels |website=The Guardian |access-date=2 September 2022 |date=30 August 2022}}</ref> On 20 June 2022, the tour removed [[Henrik Stenson]] as captain of the European [[Ryder Cup]] team as a result of his decision to join LIV Golf.<ref>{{cite web |title=Henrik Stenson joins LIV Golf series after being removed as Europe's Ryder Cup captain |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/golf/62237705 |website=BBC Sport |access-date=July 21, 2022 |date=July 20, 2022}}</ref>

==LIV Golf Invitational Series ==

===2022 season===
{{main|2022 LIV Golf Invitational Series}}

On 17 March 2022, the first eight tournament schedule with prize money of $255 million was announced by [[Greg Norman]]. The no [[cut (golf)|cut]] 54-hole tournaments feature 48 players [[draft (sport)|drafted]] into 12 four-man teams, with [[shotgun start]]s. The first seven events have $20 million purses with an additional $5 million split among the top three teams each week; a team championship concludes the schedule with $30 million on offer to the top three players and an additional $50 million in team prizes.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=DiMeglio |first=Steve |title=Greg Norman announces Saudi Arabia-backed 2022 LIV Golf Invitational Series will start in June, feature $255 million in prize money |url=https://golfweek.usatoday.com/2022/03/16/greg-norman-saudi-arabia-liv-golf-invitational-june/ |magazine=Golfweek |date=16 March 2022 |access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Beall |first1=Joel |last2=Rapaport |first2=Dan |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/liv-golf-announce-schedule-2022 |title=Saudi-backed LIV Golf announces eight-event, $255 million series that will visit United States |website=Golf Digest |date=16 March 2022 |access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Beall |first=Joel |title=Trump Doral to host $50 million LIV Golf series finale |url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/trump-doral-liv-golf |magazine=Golf Digest |date=25 April 2022 |access-date=26 April 2022}}</ref>
